natural solution: Let a common solution be $a$. Then we know \begin{align} a\equiv 3 & \pmod 4\\ a\equiv 1 & \pmod 3\\ a\equiv 1 & \pmod 5 \end{align} Since $\gcd(3,5)=1$, $(2)$ and $(3)$ together yield $a\equiv 1\pmod {3\cdot 5}$ which is the same as $a\equiv 1\pmod {15}$.
Then there exists an integer $n$ such that $a=1+15n$.

Substituting this into $(1)$ gives \[1+15n\equiv 3\pmod 4\implies n\equiv 2\pmod 4\] So $n$ has a lower bound of $2$. Then $n\ge 2\implies a=1+15n\ge 31$. $31$ satisfies the original congruences so subtracting it from both sides of each gives \begin{align}

a-31\equiv -28\equiv 0 & \pmod 4
onumber\ a-31\equiv -30\equiv 0 & \pmod 3
onumber\ a-31\equiv -30\equiv 0 & \pmod 5
onumber \end{align} Since $\gcd(3,4)=\gcd(4,5)=\gcd(3,5)=1$, we have $a-31\equiv 0\pmod {3\cdot 4\cdot 5}$, that is, $a\equiv 31\pmod{60}$.
Note that any solution of the above congruence also satisfies the original ones. Then the two solutions are $31$ and $60+31=91$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: int
assumes h0 : "x > 1"
and h1 : "x < 100"
and h2 : "y > 1"
and h3 : "y < 100"
and h4 : "x mod 4 = 3"
and h5 : "x mod 3 = 1"
and h6 : "x mod 5 = 1"
and h7 : "y mod 4 = 3"
and h8 : "y mod 3 = 1"
and h9 : "y mod 5 = 1"
shows  "x + y = 122"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two integers between 1 and 100 such that for each:

if you divide by 4, the remainder is 3;

if you divide by 3, the remainder is 1;

if you divide by 5, the remainder is 1.

What is the sum of those two integers? The final Answer is 122
 ### Proof
 Let a common solution be $a$. Then we know \begin{align} a\equiv 3 & \pmod 4\\ a\equiv 1 & \pmod 3\\ a\equiv 1 & \pmod 5 \end{align} Since $\gcd(3,5)=1$, $(2)$ and $(3)$ together yield $a\equiv 1\pmod {3\cdot 5}$ which is the same as $a\equiv 1\pmod {15}$.
 Then there exists an integer $n$ such that $a=1+15n$.
 Substituting this into $(1)$ gives \[1+15n\equiv 3\pmod 4\implies n\equiv 2\pmod 4\] So $n$ has a lower bound of $2$. Then $n\ge 2\implies a=1+15n\ge 31$. $31$ satisfies the original congruences so subtracting it from both sides of each gives \begin{align}
 a-31\equiv -28\equiv 0 & \pmod 4\nonumber\\ a-31\equiv -30\equiv 0 & \pmod 3\nonumber\\ a-31\equiv -30\equiv 0 & \pmod 5\nonumber \end{align} Since $\gcd(3,4)=\gcd(4,5)=\gcd(3,5)=1$, we have $a-31\equiv 0\pmod {3\cdot 4\cdot 5}$, that is, $a\equiv 31\pmod{60}$.
 Note that any solution of the above congruence also satisfies the original ones. Then the two solutions are $31$ and $60+31=91$.
 Thus, $31+91=\boxed{122}$.
 *)

fixes x y :: int
assumes h0 : "x > 1"
and h1 : "x < 100"
and h2 : "y > 1"
and h3 : "y < 100"

and h5 : "x mod 3 = 1"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: int
assumes h0 : "x > 1"

and h6 : "x mod 3 = 1"
and h7 : "y mod 3 = 1"
and h8 : "x mod 5 = 1"
and h9 : "y mod 5 = 1"
shows  "x + y = 122"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There are two integers between 1 and 100 such that for each:

if you divide by 4, the remainder is 3;

if you divide by 3, the remainder is 1;

if you divide by 5, the remainder is 1.

What is the sum of those two integers? The final Answer is 122
 ### Proof
 Let a common solution be $a$. Then we know \begin{align} a\equiv 3 & \pmod 4\\ a\equiv 1 & \pmod 3\\ a\equiv 1 & \pmod 5 \end{align} Since $\gcd(3,5)=1$, $(2)$ and $(3)$ together yield $a\equiv 1\pmod {3\cdot 5}$ which is the same as $a\equiv 1\pmod {15}$.
 Then there exists an integer $n$ such that $a=1+15n$.
 Substituting this into $(1)$ gives \[1+15n\equiv 3\pmod 4\implies n\equiv 2\pmod 4\] So $n$ has a lower bound of $2$. Then $n\ge 2\implies a=1+15n\ge 31$. $31$ satisfies the original congruences so subtracting it from both sides of each gives \begin{align}
 a-31\equiv -28\equiv 0 & \pmod 4\nonumber\\ a-31\equiv -30\equiv 0 & \pmod 3\nonumber\\ a-31\equiv -30\equiv 0 & \pmod 5\nonumber \end{align} Since $\gcd(3,4)=\gcd(4,5)=\gcd(3,5)=1$, we have $a-31\equiv 0\pmod {3\cdot 4\cdot 5}$, that is, $a\equiv 31\pmod{60}$.
 Note that any solution of the above congruence also satisfies the original ones. Then the two solutions are $31$ and $60+31=91$.
 Thus, $31+91=\boxed{122}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: int
assumes h0 : "x > 1"
and h1 : "x < 100"
and h2 : "y > 1"
and h3 : "y < 100"
and h4 : "x mod 4 = 3"
and h5 : "y mod 4 = 3"
and h6 : "x mod 3 = 1"
and h7 : "y mod 3 = 1"
and h8 : "x mod 5 = 1"
and h9 : "y mod 5 = 1"
shows  "x + y = 122"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find two integers $x$ and $y$ such that both are greater than 1 but less than 100, both leave a remainder of 3 when divided by 4, both leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 3, and both leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 5. The sum of these two numbers is 122.
